case_vignette:
A 40-year-old female complains about squamous papules on her scalp for 10 years. These lesions responded to topical corticosteroids but recurs when the treatment is stopped. She denies any systemic symptoms. Physical exam reveals erythematous scaly papules with signs of atrophy and scarring, as well as cicatricial alopecia. Skin biopsy shows lichenoid interface dermatitis with hyperkeratosis and follicular plugging. The patient is diagnosed with lichen planus.
The rewritten text should be a neutral, gender-neutral description of the patient and the condition.

Here is the rewritten text:

A 40-year-old patient complains about squamous papules on their scalp for 10 years. These lesions responded to topical corticosteroids but recurs when the treatment is stopped. The patient denies any systemic symptoms. Physical exam reveals erythematous scaly papules with signs of atrophy and scarring, as well as cicatricial alopecia. Skin biopsy shows lichenoid interface dermatitis with hyperkeratosis and follicular plugging. The patient is diagnosed with lichen planus.

Note: I removed the word "female" and replaced it with "patient", which is a more neutral term. I also removed the pronoun "her" and replaced it with "their", which is a more inclusive and neutral pronoun. This rewritten text maintains the same level of detail and accuracy as the original text, but presents it in a more neutral and inclusive way. 

This rewritten text is more suitable for a medical or scientific context where the focus is on the patient's condition and treatment, rather than their personal characteristics. It's worth noting that using gender-neutral language is not only a matter of politeness, but also a matter of accuracy and respect for patients' identities. Using gender-specific language can be alienating and exclusionary for patients who do not identify with the gender binary. By using neutral language, we can create a more inclusive and respectful environment for all patients. 

In addition, using gender-neutral language can also help to avoid perpetuating stereotypes and biases in medical research and practice. For example, studies have shown that women are often underrepresented in medical research and are more likely to be diagnosed with certain conditions, such as fibromyalgia. multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have scaly, red bumps on my scalp that have been there for 10 years.
Have you noticed these bumps anywhere else on your body or just the scalp?
Just on my scalp.
Do these bumps itch or cause any pain?
No, I don't have any itchiness or pain from them.
Have you used any medication or treatments for this condition in the past?
Yes, I have used topical corticosteroids which helped, but the bumps come back when I stop the treatment.
Do you have a family history of similar skin issues or any other skin diseases?
No, I don't have a family history of similar skin issues or other skin diseases.
Final Diagnosis: Psoriasis
